title: CVE-2022-24288: Apache Airflow: TWO RCEs in example DAGs

profile.name: Internet Bug Bounty
profile.about: The Internet Bug Bounty rewards security research into vulnerabilities impacting Open Source Software Projects.

activities.message:
Hi, @happyhacking123. Thank you for your submission! 

One of the tasks we have with the IBB is to connect the original reporter of the vulnerability to the submitter of the H1 report. Is there anything you can provide, like a screenshot of the original email to the Apache Software Foundation Security team (or something else), that can help link your H1 username to the reporter acknowledged in the security advisory? Any help would be appreciated!

Thank you!

Hello, this are screenshots of two RCEs emails and ASF response email I submitted. 
███
Thank you, @happyhacking123. What you've provided is perfect. I'm just working through some more checks.
The policy of the IBB is to use the severity of the CVE provided by the Project. In this case, the Apache Airflow team has designated this vulnerability as a High severity.

Thank you for your contribution to making the Internet safer!

This bounty was awarded with a 80/20% split. An additional $1,000 will be paid to the project.

summaries.content:
CVE-2022-24288: Apache Airflow: RCE in example DAGs

Severity: high

Description: In Apache Airflow, prior to version 2.2.4, some example DAGs did not properly sanitize user-provided params, making them susceptible to OS Command Injection from the web UI.

Mitigation: This can be mitigated by ensuring `[core] load_examples` is set to `False`.

Credit: The Apache Airflow PMC would like to thank Kai Zhao of the TToU Security Team for reporting this issue.

https://lists.apache.org/thread/dbw5ozcmr0h0lhs0yjph7xdc64oht23t
